citation.article-title: Gracilibacillus quinghaiensis sp. nov., isolated from salt-lake sediment in the Qaidam Basin, north-west China

p.s: Description of Gracilibacillus quinghaiensis sp. nov.
G. quinghaiensis (quing.hai.en'sis, N.L. fem. adj.) pertains to Qinghai, Western province of China, where the type strain was isolated.
Cells are motile, Gram-positive, catalase- and oxidase-positive, obligately aerobic thin rods (4–6×0.4–0.6 μm) that occur predominantly in flexible chains (4–8 cells).
Filamentous forms are present throughout the growth cycle.
They bear ellipsoidal endospores that lie in terminal swollen sporangia.
After 4–5 days on Difco marine agar 2216 at 37 °C, colonies are circular, transparent with slightly irregular margins, 1–1.5 mm in diameter.
The colour varies with culture time from creamy white to pale pink.
No diffusible pigments are produced.
Growth occurs at 4–45 °C (optimum 37 °C) and pH 6.0–8.5 (optimum pH 7.0–7.5).

It is slightly halophilic, with growth at 0.5–8% (w/v) NaCl [optimum 1–3% (w/v) NaCl], and is positive for hydrolysis of chitin, aesculin and urea, and negative for hydrolysis of casein, gelatin, starch and Tween 80.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
Voges–Proskauer and methyl red tests are negative.
H2S and indole are not produced.

It is resistant to nalidixic acid (20 μg), and sensitive to ampicillin (30 μg), chloramphenicol (30 μg), gentamicin (10 μg), kanamycin (30 μg), licomycin (2 μg), novobiocin (30 μg), polymyxin B (30 μg), rifampicin (5 μg), streptomycin (10 μg) and tetracycline (30 μg).
It gave positive results for oxidation of arabinose, inositol and sorbitol, and fermentation of glucose, and negative result for citrate utilization (API 20E).

It can produce acid from d-arabinose, d-galactose, d-glucose, inositol, d-sorbitol, d-turanose, potassium gluconate and potassium 2-ketogluconate (API 50CH) and can oxidize amygdalin, l-arabinose, arbutin, d-cellobiose, d-frucose, d-galatose, d-glucose, glycerol, myo-inositol, maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, d-raffinose, d-sorbitol, sucrose, d-trehalose, turanose, l-alanine and l-asparagine (Biolog GP2).

Constitutive enzymes expressed by YIM-C229T are acid phosphatase, alkaline phosphatase, esterase(C4), esterase lipase(C8), α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase and urease (API ZYM, API 20E).
Menaquinone 7 (MK-7) is the predominant respiratory quinone.
The polar lipids consist of diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylglycerol.
The major cellular fatty acids (making up 78.8% of the total) are anteiso-C15:0, C16:0, iso-C15:0, C16:1ω11c and anteiso-C17:0, containing meso-diamonopimelic acid in the cell-wall peptidoglycan.
The DNA G+C content is 40.9 mol%.

Phylogenetic placement based on 16S rRNA gene sequence affiliates the strain to the genus Gracilibacillus, but there is evidence for divergence from the previously recognized four species in this genus.
The type strain, YIM-C229T (=DSM 17858T=CGMCC 1.6304T), was isolated from a sediment sample collected from the Xiaochaidamu salt lake in the Qaidam Basin in Qinghai province, north-west China.
